text:
NANETTE FONDAS: I
shouldn't be here.

I'm not a professor or
a business practitioner.

I'm a mother and a part
time writer and editor.
It wasn't always this way.

I earned my doctorate right here
at HBS then worked for 11 years

before children figured
into my work life equation.

But then tick tock of
that biological clock
and I wanted a baby.

Like many of you, like
many 35-year-olds,

I found out that conceiving
that baby wasn't so easy.

And finally, baby
number one arrived

at age 37, twins at age 41, and
another singleton at age 46.

Caring for children
complicates careers
as does navigating dual careers.

I coped with my husband's job
relocations to different cities

by securing a series
of faculty positions,

but how many lateral
moves can one make?

When I hit that maternal
wall, I opted out

or, as Pam Stone
says, pushed out.

I spent the next
20 years devouring

all the motherhood literature
at home, often on the couch,

as I spent the
equivalent of eight woman
years breastfeeding.

I wanted to be with the babies
and also be a badass professor.

Like Naomi Wolf wrote
in Misconceptions,

I wanted a revolution in gender
roles and workplace practices
with respect to caregiving.
What I got was hired help.

I started to think about how
to find solutions for all moms.
I'm a Rhodes scholar.

And I wondered if influential
Rhodes women might

be well positioned and cared to
spearhead a mothers' movement.

I wrote an article
in alumni magazine

to gauge interest from that
group but found little.
So I kept reading.

And one day an email
arrived from a friend

who thought I might want to
know about a group called
Moms Rising that was forming.

I mentioned this to my
husband and he said,
first mover advantage.

You can't beat
them, so join them.

So I spearheaded Moms Rising
workplace flexibility campaigns

and wrote a book in
2010 about solutions

such as virtual
working, contracting,

return to work programs,
bringing children
to the workplace, and so forth.

But something
really gnawed at me.

I felt that we needed something
more or something different,

not just flexible work
arrangements or 12 weeks

or even 12 months of
paid parental leave,

but rather a larger
appreciation and valuation

of the work of the decades
of investment involved
in caring for family members.

We know from our personal
lives and from our research

that women still
shoulder the lion's share

of that responsibility even
when working full time.

It varies by region,
but worldwide women

spend an average of
four and 1/2 hours a day

caring for children and on
other family responsibilities.

Men spend about half of
that according to the OECD.

Economists estimate that
women around the world

work 39 days more
than men each year

caring for children,
the ill, the elderly.

Those additional days of
unpaid care work spread out

over the average life
expectancy for women

globally amounts to a
staggering 23 years of work.

Furthermore, it's usually women
who scale back their hours

or quit their paid
jobs altogether
to get the caregiving work done.

A full 42% of women
surveyed by agingcare.com

said their professional
careers had

suffered as the result
of their caregiving.

So I ask, would people care
more about all this care work
if they knew its worth?

McKinsey found that if all
unpaid work were compensated

at a rate approximating only
minimum wage, 10 trillion

would be added to global
economic output or 13% of GDP.

Unpaid care work, by
which all human capital

is created and enriched, is work
that makes capitalism possible.

It's an investment in
others yet it's also

what makes women
disproportionately poor,

lagging in leadership
representation,

and segregated into
lower paying job sectors.

Women's quest for
equality will never

be achieved until this
traditional work receives

its full worth
and consideration.

I almost didn't come
to this conference.

I felt I didn't have
empirical research to share.

And then I realized that
from my privileged position

of studying and caring
about caregiving

that I had to take this
opportunity to come,

because all of you are
influential people.

We all must care about
caregiving and not just

because we want to keep
our careers on track.

There are infants,
toddlers, teens,

and elderly people
who need us to do

what we can in our research,
in our workplaces, communities,

and families to
value and support

those caring for others, both
paid and unpaid caregivers.

Acknowledge that care work
enables other work to get done.

Insist on respect for that in
the circles that you orbit.
